title: Trap door
data:
| ^ trap door [![Trap door.png](/images/0/0e/Trap_door.png)](/wiki/File:Trap_door.png) |                                                                                                |
| ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Generates                                                                            | levels with diggable floors, [closets](/wiki/Closet "Closet"), [Castle](/wiki/Castle "Castle") |
| Effect                                                                               | Fall to lower level                                                                            |

A **trap door** is a type of [trap](/wiki/Trap "Trap") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is somewhat identical to a [hole](/wiki/Hole "Hole"): it drops any monster that steps on it to a deeper dungeon level, though it starts out hidden.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Description](#Description)

- [3 Removal](#Removal)

- [4 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [5 History](#History)

- [6 Messages](#Messages)

- [7 Variants](#Variants)

  - [7.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
    - [7.1.1 Messages](#Messages_2)
  - [7.2 UnNetHack](#UnNetHack)
  - [7.3 EvilHack](#EvilHack)

- [8 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

- [9 References](#References)

## Generation

Trap doors can be randomly generated at any dungeon level, but cannot be generated randomly beneath [boulders](/wiki/Boulder "Boulder") or on levels with non-diggable floors such as the [vibrating square](/wiki/Vibrating_square "Vibrating square") level - the [Castle](/wiki/Castle "Castle") has five statically placed trap doors that are the only entrances to the [Valley of the Dead](/wiki/Valley_of_the_Dead "Valley of the Dead"). If a trap door would be randomly generated on a level with a non-diggable floor, it is replaced with a [falling rock trap](/wiki/Falling_rock_trap "Falling rock trap").

Trap doors are sometimes found in closets, with the [engraving](/wiki/Engraving "Engraving") "[Vlad](/wiki/Vlad "Vlad") was here" in front of the door.

If you [kick](/wiki/Kick "Kick") a [throne](/wiki/Throne "Throne") and do not destroy it or knock loose treasure, there is a 1⁄4 chance of a trap door suddenly appearing; it cannot be triggered any other way, and will close up as soon as you land.

## Description

- *Main article: [Hole § Effects](/wiki/Hole#Effects "Hole")*

[You](/wiki/You "You") or another monster that steps on a trap door will fall at least one dungeon level.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)[\[2\]](#cite_note-2) As with holes, there is no upper limit, and you cannot fall beyond the Castle. It is common to fall 2 or 3 floors if you trigger a trap door, while monsters never fall more than one floor.[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)[\[4\]](#cite_note-4) [Pets](/wiki/Pet "Pet") and monsters with the [follower](/wiki/Follower "Follower") attribute that are on an adjacent square when you fall through a trap door will follow you down to whatever floor you land on.

[Pets](/wiki/Pet "Pet") that fall through a trap door while [leashed](/wiki/Leash "Leash") lose a point of [tameness](/wiki/Tameness "Tameness"), and the leash is removed. Monsters that [levitate](/wiki/Levitate "Levitate"), [fly](/wiki/Fly "Fly") or are at least huge [size](/wiki/Size "Size") cannot fall through trap doors, including you if you are levitating or in an applicable monster form - while flying above a trap door, you can press [>](/wiki/Angle_bracket "Angle bracket") to swoop down through it.

Zapping a [wand of opening](/wiki/Wand_of_opening "Wand of opening") or the [spell of knock](/wiki/Spell_of_knock "Spell of knock") at a trap door's position will trigger the trap and reveal it.[\[5\]](#cite_note-5) Zapping a [wand of locking](/wiki/Wand_of_locking "Wand of locking") or the [spell of wizard lock](/wiki/Spell_of_wizard_lock "Spell of wizard lock") at a hole will turn it into a trap door.[\[6\]](#cite_note-6) Zapping a [wand of striking](/wiki/Wand_of_striking "Wand of striking") at a trap door below you will destroy it and turn it into a hole.[\[7\]](#cite_note-7)

## Removal

A trap door can be removed by pushing a [boulder](/wiki/Boulder "Boulder") into it, or by zapping a wand of locking or the wizard lock spell at it.

## Strategy

Known trap doors can be a useful escape for you in a pinch.

## History

Trap doors first appear in [Hack 1.0](/wiki/Hack_1.0 "Hack 1.0").

In [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3"), earlier versions and some variants based on those versions, plugging all of the Castle trap doors is a [bad idea](/wiki/Bad_idea "Bad idea"), as the only other way to access the Valley of the Dead is via [branchport](/wiki/Branchport "Branchport") or a [levelport](/wiki/Levelport "Levelport") with [teleport control](/wiki/Teleport_control "Teleport control"); in the event plugging them is deemed necessary, players would always leave at least one open. As of [NetHack 3.6.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.0 "NetHack 3.6.0"), the squares containing the trap doors can be dug out if they are filled.

The ability to fly freely down trap doors was added in [NetHack 3.6.4](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.4 "NetHack 3.6.4").

## Messages

- A trap door opens up under you!

  You activated a trap door.

- Some dust swirls beneath you.

  An unseen hole was transformed into a trap door.

- The trapdoor beneath you shatters.

  You destroyed a trap door with a wand of striking, turning it into a hole.

- There's a trapdoor beneath you; it shatters.

  As above, but the trap door was hidden.

- You fall down a shaft!

  You fell 2 levels.

- You fall down a deep shaft!

  You fell 3 levels.

- You fall down a very deep shaft!

  You fell 4+ levels.

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), an [Archeologist](/wiki/Archeologist "Archeologist") [wielding](/wiki/Wield "Wield") a bullwhip will not fall through trap doors, though objects on that square may still fall through.[\[8\]](#cite_note-8)

#### Messages

- But thanks to your trusty whip ... You don't fall in.

  A trap door opened under you, but you were an Archeologist wielding a bullwhip, preventing you from falling through.

### UnNetHack

In [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack"), [the new Castle layouts](/wiki/Castle_\(UnNetHack\) "Castle (UnNetHack)") have different trap door counts and placements: nine trap doors appear on the "island" map, while three appear on the "river" map.

### EvilHack

[EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack") uses the same possible layouts for the Castle as UnNetHack above, though the river of water in the second map is replaced by [lava](/wiki/Lava "Lava").

## Encyclopedia entry

I knew my Erik too well to feel at all comfortable on jumping into his house. I knew what he had made of a certain palace at Mazenderan. From being the most honest building conceivable, he soon turned it into a house of the very devil, where you could not utter a word but it was overheard or repeated by an echo. With his trap-doors the monster was responsible for endless tragedies of all kinds.

\[ The Phantom of the Opera, by Gaston Leroux ]

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/trap.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 1292](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.6_Released/src/trap.c#L1292)
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/trap.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 2478](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.6_Released/src/trap.c#L2478)
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [include/trap.h in NetHack 3.6.6, line 87](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.6_Released/include/trap.h#L87)
4. [↑](#cite_ref-4) [src/teleport.h in NetHack 3.6.6, line 1363](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.6_Released/src/teleport.h#L1363)
5. [↑](#cite_ref-5) [src/zap.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 2494](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.6_Released/src/zap.c#L2494)
6. [↑](#cite_ref-6) [src/zap.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 2909](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.6_Released/src/zap.c#L2909)
7. [↑](#cite_ref-7) [src/zap.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 2894](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.6_Released/src/zap.c#L2894)
8. [↑](#cite_ref-8) [trap.c in SLASH'EM\_0.0.7E7F2, line 359](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/trap.c#line359 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/trap.c")

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.6. Click here for more information.](/images/5/57/Nh366-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.6. Click here for more information.")
html:
Trap door

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
^ trap door
Generates levels with diggable floors, closets, Castle
Effect Fall to lower level

A trap door is a type of trap that appears in NetHack. It is somewhat identical to a hole: it drops any monster that steps on it to a deeper dungeon level, though it starts out hidden.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Description
  • 3 Removal
  • 4 Strategy
  • 5 History
  • 6 Messages
  • 7 Variants
    • 7.1 SLASH'EM
      • 7.1.1 Messages
    • 7.2 UnNetHack
    • 7.3 EvilHack
  • 8 Encyclopedia entry
  • 9 References

Generation

Trap doors can be randomly generated at any dungeon level, but cannot be generated randomly beneath boulders or on levels with non-diggable floors such as the vibrating square level - the Castle has five statically placed trap doors that are the only entrances to the Valley of the Dead. If a trap door would be randomly generated on a level with a non-diggable floor, it is replaced with a falling rock trap.

Trap doors are sometimes found in closets, with the engraving "Vlad was here" in front of the door.

If you kick a throne and do not destroy it or knock loose treasure, there is a 1⁄4 chance of a trap door suddenly appearing; it cannot be triggered any other way, and will close up as soon as you land.

Description

Main article: Hole § Effects

You or another monster that steps on a trap door will fall at least one dungeon level.[1][2] As with holes, there is no upper limit, and you cannot fall beyond the Castle. It is common to fall 2 or 3 floors if you trigger a trap door, while monsters never fall more than one floor.[3][4] Pets and monsters with the follower attribute that are on an adjacent square when you fall through a trap door will follow you down to whatever floor you land on.

Pets that fall through a trap door while leashed lose a point of tameness, and the leash is removed. Monsters that levitate, fly or are at least huge size cannot fall through trap doors, including you if you are levitating or in an applicable monster form - while flying above a trap door, you can press > to swoop down through it.

Zapping a wand of opening or the spell of knock at a trap door's position will trigger the trap and reveal it.[5] Zapping a wand of locking or the spell of wizard lock at a hole will turn it into a trap door.[6] Zapping a wand of striking at a trap door below you will destroy it and turn it into a hole.[7]

Removal

A trap door can be removed by pushing a boulder into it, or by zapping a wand of locking or the wizard lock spell at it.

Strategy

Known trap doors can be a useful escape for you in a pinch.

History

Trap doors first appear in Hack 1.0.

In NetHack 3.4.3, earlier versions and some variants based on those versions, plugging all of the Castle trap doors is a bad idea, as the only other way to access the Valley of the Dead is via branchport or a levelport with teleport control; in the event plugging them is deemed necessary, players would always leave at least one open. As of NetHack 3.6.0, the squares containing the trap doors can be dug out if they are filled.

The ability to fly freely down trap doors was added in NetHack 3.6.4.

Messages

A trap door opens up under you!
You activated a trap door.
Some dust swirls beneath you.
An unseen hole was transformed into a trap door.
The trapdoor beneath you shatters.
You destroyed a trap door with a wand of striking, turning it into a hole.
There's a trapdoor beneath you; it shatters.
As above, but the trap door was hidden.
You fall down a shaft!
You fell 2 levels.
You fall down a deep shaft!
You fell 3 levels.
You fall down a very deep shaft!
You fell 4+ levels.

Variants

SLASH'EM

In SLASH'EM, an Archeologist wielding a bullwhip will not fall through trap doors, though objects on that square may still fall through.[8]

Messages

But thanks to your trusty whip ... You don't fall in.
A trap door opened under you, but you were an Archeologist wielding a bullwhip, preventing you from falling through.

UnNetHack

In UnNetHack, the new Castle layouts have different trap door counts and placements: nine trap doors appear on the "island" map, while three appear on the "river" map.

EvilHack

EvilHack uses the same possible layouts for the Castle as UnNetHack above, though the river of water in the second map is replaced by lava.

Encyclopedia entry

I knew my Erik too well to feel at all comfortable on jumping into his house. I knew what he had made of a certain palace at Mazenderan. From being the most honest building conceivable, he soon turned it into a house of the very devil, where you could not utter a word but it was overheard or repeated by an echo. With his trap-doors the monster was responsible for endless tragedies of all kinds.

[ The Phantom of the Opera, by Gaston Leroux ]
